instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 5v USB Type C - No 20v
threads.message:
Hello,

I have a complicated <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that came from another shop. Many parts have been screwed with including CD3215C00 area, F7000 (only one side connected), <CAPACITOR>C3000</CAPACITOR> was missing.

Replaced secondary CD3215C00 because it was very hot. Still 5v on type C charger.
SMC was shorting <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> unfortunately. Removed SMC, short gone. Replaced SMC with new one, also replaced ISL <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> because it was missing.
Connected charger on primary connector. 5v 0 amps for a few seconds then 20 volts very low amps. Thought I got it working..
Disconnected charger and tried secondary connector. Now it just stays at 5v 0.61 / 0.41 watts (I forgot the amps)
Disconnected charger and tried primary again. Same 5v 0.61 / 0.41 watts, no longer switching to 20 volts
Replaced the CD3215C00's again and was able to get 20 volts for a short time until I disconnect and reconnect to other port then it will just stay at 5v. 20v would be present as long as I keep the charger connected, but once reconnected it will be forever gone until I replace <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>.
I did this several times because either it would bring down <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> down to 2v (<CAPACITOR>C3100</CAPACITOR> / <CAPACITOR>C3200</CAPACITOR>) or it would not have <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> at all because <TRANSISTOR>Q3100</TRANSISTOR>/<TRANSISTOR>Q3200</TRANSISTOR> is not being told to switch.

I also notice that F3000 / F3010 would measure 5v, but <TRANSISTOR>Q3100</TRANSISTOR> <TRANSISTOR>Q3200</TRANSISTOR> doesn't allow the 5v to go through to <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> to power <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>, which means no <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> to power the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>'s. It would only work if I use fresh new CD3215C00's.

What could be the issue? Any advice that anyone can give me?

I may have to try a new SMC or give up since I went through a lot of chips already unless there is something I am missing.

Thanks!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 5v USB Type C - No 20v
threads.message:
"Replaced SMC with new one"
Really new???
It must be picked up from same model board.

Did you look at USB-C redriver chip?
Many times dies, with a small hole on top.
Be aware, this chip doesn't appear on schematic, nor boardview; search the forum.

Instead of changing <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>, try heating it.
If then get 20V, reflow and very gently tap it, to assure good solders.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 5v USB Type C - No 20v
threads.message:
Yes, I meant to say SMC from same model donor board. Not technically new.

Tried reflowing <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>?s many times as well as replacing. I?m 99% certain good solder.

The USB-C redriver chip that isn?t on board view / schematic near the connectors is clean with no burn marks.

I don?t have any working board to compare to.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 5v USB Type C - No 20v
threads.message:
Remove redriver chip, just in case.
You should still have a problem on USB-C controllers area.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 5v USB Type C - No 20v
threads.message: Removed re-driver, same behaviour. I found out last shop put a resistor in place of NO STUFF <CAPACITOR>C3120</CAPACITOR> (for primary) which I removed. Also seen that <RESISTOR>R5322</RESISTOR> (<SIGNAL>SMC_USBC_INT_L</SIGNAL>) not properly soldered on. Soldered new <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>'s, diode mode shows no obvious shorts. Plugged into secondary port, 5V.. 20V 0.08 amps steady. Plugged back into other port and back to same behaviour. Checked <CAPACITOR>C3208</CAPACITOR> (secondary) and 0.08 diode mode short. I don't know what is causing this to blow.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 5v USB Type C - No 20v
threads.message:
You must get the same diode mode reading on both <CAPACITOR>C3108</CAPACITOR>/208.
You could waste time after such a messed up board.
If they did such mistakes, god knows what else screewed up :(...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 5v USB Type C - No 20v
threads.message:
Good news.. I came back to this and the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>'s seem to be working better. Since I removed that resistor in place of NO STUFF <CAPACITOR>C3120</CAPACITOR>, I replaced the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips and I now get 5V.. 20V steady on both ports. I am able to disconnect and reconnect and they do not blow. However, each port is drawing 0 amps.
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> = 3.4v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 0v.. checking ISL.
